Award.AbstractNarration: This award is made as part of the FY 2012 Mathematical Sciences Postdoctoral Research Fellowships Program. These fellowships support a research and training plan at a host institution in the mathematical sciences, including applications to other disciplines. The title of the research fellowship awarded to Adam J. Jacob is "Geometric evolution equations on complex manifolds." The host institution for the fellowship is Harvard University, and the sponsoring scientist is Dr. Shing-Tung Yau.

POR.DRECONTENT:
During the award period the PI investigated several important projects related to partial differential equations on complex manifolds. These projects had impact on a diverse range of mathematical fields, and explored connections with theoretical physics. 

First we describe the intellectual merit of the research, which consisted of three main projects. In the first project, the PI studied limiting properties of the Yang-Mills flow, an evolution equation designed to minimize a particular energy. The limiting equation, called the Yang-Mills equation, has applications to particle physics, and solutions reveal important algebraic and topological information about the underlying geometric object. The Yang-Mills equation was also the main focus of study in the second project, where the PI looked at a particular two dimensional representation of the equation, and proved solutions exists if and only if a certain algebraic stability condition is verified. Finally, the PI investigated an important equation called the deformed Hermitian-Yang-Mills equation. This equation is defined on the same background space as the Yang-Mills equation, but in practice has very different behavior and properties. It arises from the conjectural picture of mirror symmetry put forth by Strominger-Yau-Zaslow, which has been an important driving force of contemporary research in both geometry and physics. It relates to the problem of existence of special Lagrangian submanifolds of a Calabi-Yau variety, which has ramifications in a diverse range of fields, including the study of minimal submanifolds. The PI investigated techniques to solve the deformed Hermitian-Yang-Mills equation, including defining a geometric flow related to the mean curvature flow, and showed existence was equivalent to existence of a (suitably defined) subsolution. 

Now we discuss the broader impacts of the work preformed during the award period. The final products of the PI’s research during this time are broadly disseminated. Several academic research papers directly resulted from the grant and appear in the online electronic preprint database arXiv and on the PI’s webpage, as well as in traditional printed journals. In addition the PI spoke about these results at numerous seminars, workshops, and conferences. Because of the physical motivation behind Mirror symmetry and the deformed Hermitian-Yang-Mills equations, the PI participated in cross-disciplinary collaboration, communicating with physicists at Harvard and talking in the physical mathematics seminar at the Center of Mathematical Sciences and Applications.

Furthermore, during this time, the PI worked to advance the participation of both graduate and undergraduate students in mathematics and the sciences. This work included teaching three upper divisor mathematics courses at Harvard University, reaching out to both mathematics majors and students from other disciplines, and mentoring one Harvard undergraduate, Nikhil Mehra, on his senior thesis. The PI advanced graduate learning at Harvard as well, by teaching a graduate topics class on a current research subject, and by participating in S.-T. Yau’s graduate student seminar, which thoroughly exposes graduate students to the state of contemporary research in mathematics. Finally, the PI aided in service to the department by sitting on the graduate student selection committee for two years.
